body:
Calculating your profit margin is dependent on your operating costs and pricing strategy.


Let's see how to:

  • Calculate your company's profit or loss 

  • Set a profitable price for your product 

  • Calculate how many units you need to sell to cover your costs (break even) 

  • Ensure your business is scalable
title: Calculating costs, pricing and profit

body: The costs that your business incurs can be divided into two main types - fixed costs and variable costs.

_items.body:
These are costs that you would incur whether you sold one or 1000 units. 


For example: your website, salaries for your core staff team, office costs.


These are sometimes called overheads.
_items.title: Fixed costs
Variable costs
_items.body:
Costs which increase for each unit you sell.


For example, the cost of packaging and delivering the product to a customer, and the commission to the salesperson who sold the product.


Sometimes, variable costs are called cost of sales because they represent how much it costs the business to sell each unit.

title: Key concept: Types of costs

body: Simon Stockley, a senior member of the teaching faculty at Cambridge's Judge Business School, talks us through some examples of fixed and variable costs.
title: Types of cost explained

_media._source: C8M1 : Types of Costs from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Profit can be described at three different levels.

_items.body:
All the money coming in from sales or other activities. 


This is raw income, without anything deducted. 


It is also called turnover.
_items.title: Revenue

_items.body:
Gross profit is your revenue (all the money coming in) minus your variable costs (for example, packaging and delivery). 


Calculation:

Gross profit = gross revenue - variable costs
_items.title: Gross profit

_items.body:
Net profit is the money left over when you get your gross profit and subtract your fixed costs (for example, office space, salaries and insurance).


This shows how much is really left in your company's bank account at the end of the day.


Calculation:

Net profit = gross profit - fixed costs
_items.title: Net profit

title: Key concept: Profits and pricing

body:
Sometimes, rather than expressing net profit as a number, businesses express it as a percentage.


This is what we call a profit margin and it shows the proportion of revenue which ends up as net profit. 


Here's the formula to calculate profit margin:


Gross margin (%) = (gross rofit / revenue) x 100


This is important to bear in mind when you work out how much you should be charging for your products. 


You can use profit margins to set a comfortable price for your product, and it can show the high risk of reducing a product's price to get more customers.


You may well be better off having less customers buying your product at a higher price.
title: Calculating costs and margins

_media._source: C8M1 : Profit Margin from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
David Thomson, at the University of Cambridge, is an experienced retail entrepreneur.


He talks us through the costs of running a bricks and mortar shop versus running an online shop.
displayTitle: Founders' stories: Costs and profit margins in traditional vs digital retail
title: Founders' stories: Costs and profit margins in traditional vs digital retail

_media._source: C8M1 : Bricks & Mortar vs Digital from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
To break-even you need the number of sales to cover all your fixed and variable costs. 


Calculating this is a three step solution. 


1. Calculate your gross profit (sales revenue - variable costs).

2 .Calculate your gross profit margin (gross profit / revenue).

3. Calculate your break even point (fixed costs/ gross profit margin).
title: Key concept: Break even

body:
In the following example, we show how to calculate break even for a British company that makes small components for audio speakers.


The video also looks at their profit margins and shows how reducing their pricing would significantly increase their break even point, and therefore the number of customers they need to get to cover their costs.


Big Hint!

The main message here is to only use discounting with caution!
title: Case study: Calculating break even

_media._source: C8M1 - Breakeven Point from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
A scalable business is one that can continue to sell many more units without significantly increasing its fixed costs.


By checking early on that your business is scalable, you won't fall into the trap of being a 'busy fool' - working very hard to get more sales just to keep up with growing costs.


Simon talks us through some examples.
title: Key concept: Scalability

_media._source: C8M1 : Scalability from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Match the best definitions for the following keywords.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


  • A fixed cost stays the same as unit sales increases 
  • A variable cost that goes up as unit sales increases 
  • Gross Revenue is the raw amount of money coming in - not to be confused with Gross Profit which is Gross Revenue - Variable Costs

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
That's right!


  • A fixed cost stays the same as unit sales increases
  • A variable cost that goes up as unit sales increases
  • Gross Revenue is the raw amount of money coming in - not to be confused with Gross Profit which is Gross Revenue - Variable Costs

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


  • A fixed cost stays the same as unit sales increases
  • A variable cost that goes up as unit sales increases
  • Gross Revenue is the raw amount of money coming in - not to be confused with Gross Profit which is Gross Revenue - Variable Costs

_items.text: Fixed cost

_options.text: A cost that stays the same whether you sell 1 or 1000 units. For example, salaries or office rent
A cost that goes up with the number of units you sell. For example, raw materials or delivery costs
The price customers are charged for an item

_items.text: Variable cost

_options.text: The total money coming in, minus fixed costs
The total money coming in, minus variable costs

_items.text: Gross revenue

title: Key terms

You are running a fresh flower subscription website which delivers flowers to customers' offices every week. 


Are these costs fixed or variable?

_feedback.correct:

Fixed costs would be 


  • Building the website initially
  • Maintaining the website
  • Paying for the website domain


Variable costs would be


  • Advertising costs for a Mothers Day campaign

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
That's right!

  • Maintaining the website
  • Paying for the website domain


Variable costs would be:


  • Advertising costs for a Mothers Day campaign

_incorrect.final:

Fixed costs would be :

  • Maintaining the website

Maintaining the website
Paying for the website domain

title: Key terms in action

body: Match the best definition to each option.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


  • Gross profit = Total revenue - variable costs
  • Net profit = Gross profit - fixed costs
  • Profit margin expressed as a % = Net profit / sales revenue x 100

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


  • Gross profit = Total revenue - variable costs
  • Net profit = Gross profit - fixed costs
  • Profit margin expressed as a % = Net profit / sales revenue x 100

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure that's right? 


  • Gross profit = Total revenue - variable costs
  • Net profit = Gross profit - fixed costs
  • Profit margin expressed as a % = Net profit / sales revenue x 100

_items.text: Gross profit
Net profit
Profit margin expressed as a percentage

title: Types of profit

body:
Now you know the three key concepts of costs, profits and price, and scalability.


Costs can be fixed or variable.


Profit can be expressed as gross profit (without variable costs), net profit (without variable or fixed costs), or as a margin (as a percentage of gross revenue from each product).


It is important to take profit margins into account when calculating a price for your product. 


Scalability is how to make sure your business model isn't going to turn you into a 'busy fool', working ever harder to keep up with creeping fixed costs.
title: Calculating cost, price and profit. Let's wrap it up

body:
These are the 3 main documents that a business needs to produce every year to show how they are performing with shareholders, as well as the tax office. 


Let's look at interpreting:

  • A profit and loss statement
  • A balance sheet 
  • A cash flow statement
title: Text Title

body:
This is a record of a business' revenue and expenditure over the course of a year. 


It has to be filed with Companies House each year. This document is useful as it summarises the business' key:

  • Financial reports
  • Owners, lenders, investors
  • Profit or losses, and how they arose 
  • Profitability ratios


The profit and loss does not show:

  • How healthy a business' cash flow is (cash flow statement)
  • How the business is funded (balance sheet)
  • The business' health at a particular point in time (balance sheet)
title: Key document: Profit and loss

body: Simon talks us through the contents and purpose of this key document.
_source: C8M2 : Profit & Loss Statement from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
title: Case study: Profit and loss

body:
The balance sheet is a snapshot of the business' financial health. 


It needs to be submitted to Companies House every year. It shows the following.


What the business owns

These are called assets.

For example, a piece of software which it licences out, cash in the bank, money which customers owe you, office furniture and the printer. 

  

What the business owes

These are called liabilities.

For example, credit cards, money owed to our suppliers, money we need to pay in tax.


Don't worry if you don't grasp all the concepts here, just understanding what a balance sheet does and what is in it should be enough to get you started!
title: Key document: Balance sheet

_source: C8M2 : The Balance Sheet Explained from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
body: Simon walks us through some examples of balance sheets, including what is in a balance sheet and how to read one.
title: Case study: Balance sheet

body:
Cash flow is how much money you have in the bank. 


A profitable business can still go bust if you don't have enough cash to pay your staff or your suppliers when you need it.


For example, a customer hasn't paid you on time or you have incurred an unexpected last-minute cost. 


A cash flow statement shows month by month how much money is forecast to be in your bank account at the end of each month.
title: Key document: Cash flow

body: Peter Hiscocks talks us through an example of a cash flow statement.
_source: C8M1 : Cashflow introduction from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
title: Case study: Cash flow statement

body: Match the descriptions to one of the 3 key financial documents.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


The Profit & Loss describes the past

The Balance Sheet describes the present

The Cashflow Statement describes the future

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


The Profit & Loss describes the past

The Balance Sheet describes the present

The Cashflow Statement describes the future

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


The Profit & Loss describes the past

The Balance Sheet describes the present

The Cashflow Statement describes the future

_items.text: A document describing the past - the company's profits and losses. Compulsory to submit to Companies House each year.
A document describing the company's present - their current assets and liabilities. Compulsory to submit to Companies House each year.
A document describing a company's future - how much cash it thinks it will have in the bank each month. Not compulsory for Companies House but investors and the board will certainly want to see it!

title: Key financial documents

body: Which two of the following options would count as liabilities on a balance sheet?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Any money that you owe is counted as a ''liability''.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Any money that you owe is counted as a ''liability''.

_items.text: Money you owe your suppliers
Money you owe investors
Money your customers owe you
Money you have in the bank

title: Balance sheet

body:
A profitable business can still go bankrupt if it does not have enough cash flow.


Is this true of false?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


If customers are late paying, for example, a business could run out of cash and be unable to pay its' suppliers and staff. That is why it is crucial to set strict payment terms with customers early on.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


If customers are late paying, for example, a business could run out of cash and be unable to pay its' suppliers and staff. That is why it is crucial to set strict payment terms with customers early on.

_items.text: True
False

title: Cash flow

body:
The three fundamental documents a business produces are:

  • Profit and loss (past accounts)
  • Balance sheet (present snapshot)
  • Cash flow statements (future forecasts)


Depending on it's size and what it sells, it may also have other documents to submit to Companies' House every year.
title: Financial statements: Profit, loss and cash flow

body:
There are two fundamental concepts around business finance that all business owners need to know about.


Let's have a look at these.

  • How equity can be shared fairly with investors and co-founders.
  • When and how to get professional financial advice.
title: Text Title

body:
When you set up your company you decide how many shares to have and how much they are worth. 


You will also need to decide how to divide your shares between the founding team members. There are many things to consider when you make these key decisions.


Simon talks us through an example of how startup founders might come to agree on how to allocate shares before the company has even started trading.
title: Founders equity split

_media._source: C8M2 : The Balance Sheet Explained from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Share vesting is a crucial concept when it comes to dividing equity and keeping the loyalty of your team.


Simon explains the concept of share vesting and how it can help your business.
title: Vested shares

_media._source: C8M3 : Share Vesting from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Simon discusses some of the issues and his experiences of giving away equity to non-executive directors, plus some insights from early-stage entrepreneur Nick Hatter.
displayTitle: Founder stories: Sharing equity in the early days
_source: C8M3 : Founder's Experience Sharing Equity in the early days from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
title: Founder stories: Sharing equity in the early days

body: There may well come a time when it is worthwhile investing in professional help to manage and plan your finances.

_items.body: Work closely with financial advisers and make sure that they feel they are a key part of your business. They can only provide effective advice if you provide them with the information they need in a timely manner.
_items.title: Stay close
Get what you need out of it
_items.body:
Make sure that financial advisers provide you with decision making information in a format that works for you.


This includes the management accounts that help you to make decisions about your business (profit and loss, balance sheet and cash flow statements).
Get to grips with the key issues relating to finance within your business. Learn the vocabulary so you can expertly discuss these issues with your financial advisers.
_items.title: Get them to teach you
Know what you can and cannot delegate
_items.body:
Know what you can and cannot delegate to a bookkeeper or accountant.  For example, you need to be able to control your cash. 


You are in charge of and responsible for the business. You need to actively manage its finances and make key decisions.

_items.title: Define key performance indicators (KPI)
_items.body: Work with your accountant to define key performance indicators. KPI are the measures, such as financial, that help you to know how well the business is doing.
Make sure your accountant or bookkeeper supports you in complying with financial reporting requirements and regulations.
_items.title: Get their help fulfilling your reporting requirements

title: Get professional financial advice

body:
Every year you will need to file financial reports and pay taxes. Exactly what you will need to do depends on the type of your company,  its size, and how many employees you have. 


As well as the key financial reports like profit and loss and balance sheet, you might also be liable for payment of a number of taxes including National Insurance, Pay As You Earn, VAT and corporation taxes. It is advisable to get the correct systems in place from the outset. 


It's also a good idea to review HMRC guides on self-employment and starting a business to get familiar with all the varieties of business and your role in it. 


It is also advisable that you work with a financial professional to ensure that all your requirements are met. 


Show me - HMRC self-employment guides
title: Your legal responsibilities: Company finance

body: Which of the following is most helpful to decide how much equity to allocate to each founder?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


While many factors can influence a decision on dividing co-founder equity, the overarching principle is to consider how much value a team member will bring going forward.

_feedback.correct:
That's right. 


While many factors can influence a decision on dividing co-founder equity, the overarching principle is to consider how much value a team member will bring going forward.

_items.text: Who had the initial idea
How much experience each person has
How much value each person can add to the business going forward

title: Equity between co-founders

body: What does vesting shares mean?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Vested shares can only be claimed once pre-agreed milestones are met.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Vested shares can only be claimed once pre-agreed milestones are met.

_items.text: Investing the company's money in stock and shares so that it gathers value rather than sitting in a bank account

Making the allocation of shares to a core or non-core team member conditional on specific contributions being made to the business.
For example, working for a specific time or raising a specified amount of funding.
A type of share than cannot go up or down in value

title: Equity vesting

body:
A professional financial adviser can take responsibility for every aspect of a company's finances.


Is this true of false?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


A CEO always needs to be able to control your cash. They are also legally responsible for ensuring that the taxes are paid, documents are submitted to companies house and the company is complying with financial regulations.

_feedback.correct:
That's right.


A CEO always needs to be able to control your cash. They are also legally responsible for ensuring that the taxes are paid, documents are submitted to Companies House, and the company is complying with financial regulations.

_items.text: True
False

title: Professional financial advice

body:
Dividing equity between co-founders is not an exact science, but it is useful to focus on how much value each member will bring to the company in future. 


You should ensure that all shares are vested so that equity does not have to be given away without adequate contributions being made. 


At some point, it may be worth getting financial advice. Try to work closely with advisers so you can learn from them.


Make sure you are still closely involved with the finances of the business, as the CEO remains ultimately responsible.
title: Equity and financial advice. Let's wrap it up

body:
Managing the daily financial needs of your business is pretty important.


Let's have a look at:

  • How to put together a cash flow forecast
  • How to use a cash flow forecast to plan how much money you will need to launch your business 
  • How to manage your company's money efficiently
title: Intro

body:
A cash flow forecast is a month by month breakdown of  money moving in and out of your business each month, and how much you will have left in your bank account.


It can answer questions like:

  • How much money do I need to start my business?
  • When will I be able to pay myself?


Simon talks us through some examples of cash flow forecasting.
displayTitle: How much money will I need?
title: How much money will I need?

_media._source: C8M4 : How much money will you need in future? from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Here are some top tips for making your cash flow work for you.

_items.title: Make your assumptions as good as they can be
_items.body:
When you are starting out, it will be largely based on assumptions. When investors or banks look at it, they will be asking you what those assumptions are based on! 


Make the effort to gather as much research and evidence as possible as to why you think you will make 20 sales in the third month and why you think your head of marketing will cost you 50,000 in the first year.

_items.title: Don't be overly optimistic
_items.body:
The figures in your cash flow statement should reflect your research and evidence about how money will come in and go out. 


They should not be reverse engineered to show the cash flow you would like to see.  


Being overly optimistic will only make you look inexperienced to investors.

If you know any experienced entrepreneurs, get them to review your cash flow and encourage them to challenge your assumptions about how much things will cost and how long things will take. 


The more mature your business is, the better your assumptions will become and the more accurate your forecasting will become.
_items.title: Get a second pair of eyes if you can
Set strict payment terms with your clients
_items.body:
A profitable business can still go bust if customers don't pay on time and your cash flow runs dry. 


From the outset, put strict terms and conditions in place to make sure your customers pay promptly. 


Don't be shy about asking for cash on delivery, for example, if that is what suits you best. If big clients push back, don't be afraid to explain that you are a small business so prompt payment is paramount for you.

title: Top tips: Cash flow forecasting

body: David Thompson, serial entrepreneur, talks about how he managed his money in the early days of his business.
title: Founders' stories: Keeping financial control

_media._source: C8M3 - David Thompson - Keeping Financial Control from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Whether you are looking at your own financial reports or another company's documents, how can you make sense of the financial information to see if a business is doing well?


Once you have two or three years of information, the following calculations can help you to get a sense of a business's general health.


You don't need to know all of these but picking one or two might be useful checks for you.
displayTitle: How can you tell if your business is doing well?

_items.body:
Gross profit margin (as a percentage)


Gross profit / sales revenue. Gross profit is the real income of the business.


Gross profit margins vary greatly from industry to industry.


Look for stable or increasing margins over time. Falling

margins may suggest rising levels of competition and

downward pressure on prices, or an increase in costs

directly associated with the product or service.
_items.title: Gross profit margin
Net profit margin
_items.body:
Net profit margin is before interest payable and tax / sales revenue.


Net profit is the income remaining once overheads

(fixed costs) have been deducted from gross profits. 


It is a good measure of the operating efficiency of a

business. Like gross margin, look for stable or

increasing margins.

_items.title: Return on capital employed (ROCE) percentage
_items.body:
Net profit before interest and tax / (total assets current liabilities)


ROCE shows how effectively the capital employed

(owner's equity and long term loans) are being used to

generate profits. 


Equity investors are particularly interested in this figure. Generally speaking the higher the figure, the better.

(Fixed costs / gross profit margin) / sales revenue.


The break-even point as a percentage of turnover tells

you much about how scalable a business is. 


A falling figure suggests scalability; a rising trend suggests the opposite.
_items.title: Break-even point as a percentage of turnover

title: How can you tell if your business is doing well?

body: Liquidity ratios tell us about the ability of the business to pay its bills and how well credit is controlled.

_items.body:
Current assets / current liabilities.


It gives an indication about your ability to pay bills (your liquidity). 


A figure above 2 is considered very healthy.

Above 1 is healthy in a startup. 

A figure below 1 might be a cause for concern.

A falling trend over time indicates a decline in a companys liquidity.
_items.title: Current ratio

_items.body:
(Current assets stock) / current liabilities.


This is a tougher test of liquidity than the current ratio.


Generally, anything over 1 is considered to be healthy.

Again, beware of falling trends.
_items.title: Quick ratio

_items.body:
(Trade debtors / sales revenue) x 365


This shows the number of days it takes a business to get

paid. It's a good measure of how effective you are at

controlling the credit you offer to customers.
_items.title: Debtor days
Creditor days
_items.body:
(Trade creditors / cost of goods sold) x 365


It shows how long (in days) it takes for you to pay your

suppliers (trade creditors). 


If this figure is creeping up, it is often a warning sign of cash flow problems.

title: Liquidity ratios

body: Financing ratios tell us about the relative proportions of debt and equity used to fund the business.

_items.body:
(Long-term debt + short-term debt + bank overdrafts) / owner's equity


Gearing is the proportion of a company's debt to its

equity. 


A highly geared company has a high proportion of debt to equity. Lenders and investors use gearing as an indicator of financial risk. 


This is because debt needs to be serviced with regular payments which can cause problems if the companys trading performance declines. 


Highly geared businesses are also vulnerable to changes in interest rates.
_items.title: Gearing (as a percentage)

_items.body:
A multiple, for example, 4.5x


Net profit before interest payable and tax / loan interest payable.


This ratio is often used by banks to check that a business can afford to meet interest payments on money they have borrowed.
_items.title: Interest cover

_items.body:
A multiple, for example, 3x


Net profit before interest payable and tax / debt repayments.


Closely related to interest cover but also includes

repayments to the loan principal (the amount you

borrowed). 


So when you repay a loan, part of the payment covers  interest and part repays the sum borrowed.
_items.title: Debt cover

title: Financing ratios

body: Which two of the following are common errors when constructing a cash flow forecast?
displayTitle: How much money will I need?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


It often takes longer than estimated to make the first sales or be able to draw a salary. Being overly optimistic can make you look inexperienced to investors.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


It often takes longer than estimated to make the first sales or be able to draw a salary. Being overly optimistic can make you look inexperienced to investors.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


It often takes longer than estimated to make the first sales or be able to draw a salary. Being overly optimistic can make you look inexperienced to investors.

_items.text: It takes longer than you anticipated to make sales
Being overly conservative
It takes longer than you anticipated to get paid
It takes less time than you anticipated to raise money

title: How much money will I need?

body: Which one of the following items would you NOT expect to see on a cash flow forecast?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure? 


You would expect to see rent, tax and expenditure on the cash flow forecast but not depreciation.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


You would expect to see rent, tax and expenditure on the cash flow forecast but not depreciation.

_items.text: Expenditure on fixed assets
Rent payments
Depreciation - the loss in the value of fixed assets like buildings
Tax payments

title: Cash flow forecasts

body: Which one of the following is NOT a main use for a cash flow forecast?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


The Profit & Loss and Balance Sheet are compulsory documents to submit to Companies' House but not the cashflow statement.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


The profit & loss and balance sheet statements are compulsory documents to submit to Companies House, but not the cash flow statement.

_items.text: Providing early warning of cash shortages
Planning the amount and timing of external funding
Scenario planning
Reporting to Companies House

title: Cash flow forecast purpose

body:
A cash flow forecast will tell you how much money you will need to get your business off the ground. That is, the lowest number in your cash flow statement. 


Ratios are used to analyse a company's key financial documents - the profit and loss, balance sheet and cash flow forecast - to make a judgement as to its financial health. 


Experienced entrepreneurs advised on the importance of keeping on top of your finances, the value of investing in some digital software and picking some key financial metrics to track so that you don't get lost in the data.
title: Manage your day to day finances. Let's wrap it up

body:
You need a funding strategy. This covers how much money you ask for, when you ask for it, and who you ask.


Who you can ask to invest will depend on the type of business you are planning and the stage you're at.


One thing for sure is that raising money takes longer than you think.


If investors know you are desperate you are less likely to be in a good position to negotiate a good deal on either

interest or how much equity you give them.


 Let's have a look at:

  • How to work out when to start asking for money
  • How to work out how much equity you need to give away
title: Text Title

body:
If you mock up your cash forecast but don't include any external funding, you will see the depth of your valley of death. 


What is the valley of death, you ask?


It's your debt until you start making money and rebuilding those reserves of cash to start paying back what you've borrowed.
displayTitle: How much investment do I need?
title: How much investment do I need?

_media._source: C9M4 - Funnel Case Studies from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: How long will it take to raise investment?
body:
Raising funding is like a long football game - there is a beginning, middle and end. 


It takes 6-12 months to raise a round of funding (and with no guarantees that you will be successful). 


So start early. If you approach investors when you are already desperate for money, you are not in a good position to negotiate good terms on interest or equity. 


Experienced investor John Yeomans shares his experiences of helping startups raise their first pot of money.
title: How long will it take to raise investment?

body:
Simon explains the danger of leaving fundraising too late. 


If you are in a desperate position, you are more likely to need to give away more equity in exchange for investment.
_source: C8M4 : bargaining power and time from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
title: Timing and bargaining power

_source: C9M4 - Funnels with cohorts from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
displayTitle: How much equity do you need to give away?
body:
How much equity you give away for investment will depend on what your business is valued at.


So how do you work it out so early on?
title: How much equity do you need to give away?

body: Here is a quick recap of equity.

_items.body:
The value of your business before the investment. 


Calculation:

(Investment money / investment stake) -investment money
_items.title: Pre-money valuation
Post-money valuation
_items.body:
The value of the business once the investment is in. 


Calculation:

Investment amount / equity stake

title: Recap: Key terms and concepts

body:
Here are some things which increase the value of your business to investors. 


An idea with no proof of market or registered IP has no commercial value yet.

_items.title: Intellectual property
_items.body: A secured patent.
This might also include top class non-executive directors.
_items.title: Recruit a solid founding team
Proof of concept
_items.body:
Run a pilot with a minimum viable product. 


This could generate an example proof of market.
For example, key partnerships secured or a reference from an industry leading client.
_items.title: Strategic alliances

_items.body: For example, early seed funding or grant funding which has been secured.
_items.title: Funding obtained

title: What can affect your valuation?

body:
Let's get two points of view about the experiences of raising capital. 


Alex Van Someren from Amadeus Capital talks about how he values the business. For him, team skill and commitment is the most important.


David Gill, an experienced investor, talks about how he makes decisions to invest in startups.

_incorrect.body: Incorrect answer, click continue to try again
_incorrect.title: Incorrect

_items.optionText: Click here to hear from David

title: Founder stories: Early valuation

body:
Take an investor's viewpoint.

What would a very short and shallow valley of death, followed by a huge sales revenue, suggest to an investor?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Don't underestimate how long it will take for your to gain traction and revenue. Being unrealistic could be a ''turn-off'' for investors.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Don't underestimate how long it will take for your business to gain traction and revenue. Being unrealistic could be a 'turn-off' for investors.

_items.text: The business model needs more work
The opportunity is too good to miss
Weak competition
Wait until they need the money

title: How much will you need?

body: What period of time should you allow to raise funds from a business angel?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


It might take between 6-18 months before raising the money you need so it's worth starting early.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


It might take 6-18 months before you can raise the money you need, so it's worth starting early.

_items.text: 1 - 3 months
6 -18 months
Wait until you need the money

title: How long will it take?

body: What is a pre-money valuation?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Pre-money evaluation is the value of all the company's shares before it takes on investment.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Pre-money evaluation is the value of all the company's shares before it takes on investment.

_items.text: The value of a company's shares business before it starts trading
The value of a company's shares before it takes on investment

title: Pre-money valuations

body:
When it comes to investors, start early.


It can easily take a year to get the funding you need. If you are desperate you might look amateurish at financial planning or be vulnerable to a bad deal. 


Be realistic about how much you will need to get going and how strong the returns are going to be. All experienced investors understand that to deliver strong returns, you initially need a high level of risk. 


Different investors value early stage startups using different measures. 


This can include the team being in place, having a prototype, or having a patent secured. Focus on reaching these milestones first. With no evidence of demand or patent there's not much commercial value for an investor.
title: Raising your first investment funds. Let's wrap it up

body:
There are many types of funding you might want to secure for your business.


These include:

  • Grant funding 
  • Debt funding 
  • Equity funding
title: Text Title

body:
Grants are money from the government or charities which help you to develop your business. 


Their main characteristic is that you don't have to pay them back! 


That said, they don't come without strings attached.
title: Pros of grants

_items.title: You often need to spend your own money up front and reclaim the grant money to reimburse yourself
It often comes with strict limitations on how it can be spent
It can require hefty reporting back to donors or awarding bodies
They might not give you all the money you need

body:
Debt is another word for loans. 


Banks only give loans to businesses who are already making revenue (because they know they will need cash to pay interest on the loan). Interest rates are usually in line with credit card rates. 


They may well ask for personal guarantees to be held against the loan, such as your house or your car.  If you default on the loan, they can force you to sell personal assets to repay the loan if your business doesn't work out.


The main benefit is that you don't have to give away shares of your business but as you have seen - it comes at a high risk!
title: Debt

body: Let's hear more about the pros and cons of debt funding.
title: Debt based funding

_media._source: C8M5 : Debt Based Funding from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Entrepreneurs might raise funding by giving away equity to:

  • Business angels
  • Seed funds and venture investors
  • Crowdfunding


Giving away equity changes the number of shares each co-founder owns and what the value of those shares are.
title: Understanding equity

_media._source: C8M5 : Debt Based Funding from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

title: Founder stories: Investor and  entrepreneur. What makes a good match?

body: What is the main reason that banks and other providers of debt finance do not lend to pre-revenue stage startups?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


It is extremely rare for banks to lend to businesses who can't prove they could pay interest on a loan.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


It is extremely rare for banks to lend to businesses who can't prove they can pay interest on a loan.

_items.text: The entrepreneurs are likely to be inexperienced
The risk of competition
They don't trust entrepreneurs
The business does not have the cash flow needed to service the debt

title: Debt funding

body: What are two drawbacks to grant funding?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Grants are great because they don't need to be paid back. However, they often need to be spent on very specific things and can come with hefty reporting requirements.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Grants are great because they don't need to be paid back. However, they often need to be spent on very specific things and can come with hefty reporting requirements.

_items.text: It often needs to be spent on very specific things
It needs to be paid back
It often comes with hefty reporting requirements

title: Grant funding

body: What are the three advantages of equity as a form of investment?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Equity can be great for start-ups as it often comes with advice, is available pre-revenue and doesn't need you to have cash to repay loans for example.


You do however need to give away a proportion of your shares in exchange for the early investment.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Equity can be great for startups as it often comes with advice. It is also often available pre-revenue and doesn't need you to have cash, to repay loans for example. 


You do however need to give away a proportion of your shares in exchange for the early investment.

_items.text: It usually comes with advice
You don't need to give away a share of your business
You do not need to make regular repayments
It is often available before you are generating sales revenue

title: Equity funding

body:
If you need money to get your business going, consider the possibilities of grants, equity, and debt funding. 


They each have their pros and cons and each can be useful at different stages of your journey.
title: Grant, debt and equity funding. Let's wrap it up
